Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Petal NGL Terminal resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  Other recommendations for possible changes to improve safety come from periodic accident prevention program audits, incident investigations, or employee suggestions and recommendations.  The following changes are planned for implementation at the Petal NGL Terminal.

* No changes are planned.

Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures.
* Personnel protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.)

Five Year Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

This facility has had no accidental releases in the last five years which meets the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10.

Emergency Procedures Information

The Petal NGL Terminal maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The procedures are for the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs.  Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  The emergency procedure is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the terminal facilities.   

The overall emergency procedure program for the Petal NGL Terminal is coordinated with the Forrest and Lamar Counties Local Emergency Management District (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives.  The Petal NGL Terminal has around-the- clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Petal NGL Terminal conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and also provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of reg

h the use of written operating procedures, employee training in written procedures, including normal operation and emergency release procedures, and in the design of safety and release prevention equipment installed at the terminal site.  In addition, a written safety program designed to comply with all applicable OSHA safety performance regulations is strictly enforced at all Enterprise facilities, including the Petal NGL Terminal facility.  As part of the Enterprise safety program, the facility utilizes procedures that are included in the Enterprise program, but may not specifically be required at non-PSM and/or RMP Program 1 facilities (e.g. Safe work practice training; safe work permitting and hot work permitting).

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP covered processes at Petal NGL Terminal.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Petal NGL Terminal has safety features on many units to help contain/control a release, to quickly detect a release and reduce the consequence of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection

* Hydrocarbon (hazardous gas) detectors and alarms
* Terminal video surveillance system

Release Containment and Control

* Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).
* Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high pressure).
* Secondary containment (curbs and dikes) to contain any release of liquid chemicals
* Redundant equipment and instrumentation where advisable
* Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation

* Hand-held fire extinguishers
* Deluge system and fire water monitors
* Diesel fire water pump and fire water system
*

inal source of the product. Propane and commercial butane are transferred to underground storage wells for long term storage. The propane and commercial butane, along with a relatively pure liquid ethane product, are handled by the nearby Petal Storage Facility. The ethane is received from PHMSA regulated pipelines, sent to storage in an underground liquid storage well, and is returned to PHMSA regulated pipelines from storage.  The ethane, propane and commercial butane stored at Petal is in storage incident to PHMSA pipeline transportation and is exempt from the EPA Risk Management Program regulation. Up to 1,200 gallons of ethyl mercaptan is also stored at the facility for use as an odorant in rail car and transport truck propane shipments.  The quantity of ethyl mercaptan in storage is at all times less than the 10,000 pound threshold quantity specified in the EPA RMP regulation.

The Petal NGL Terminal is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 1 facility.

Toxics

There are no toxic materials contained on site above the threshold limits.

Flammables

The Petal NGL Terminal was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable substances exceeded the threshold quantity.  Listed flammable substances which are present above the threshold quantities at the Petal NGL Terminal are propane and commercial butane.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The offsite consequence analysis will not be reflected in the executive summary but rather is reflected in the data components.  There are flammable substances on site and no toxic substances above the threshold quantity.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the accidental release prevention program in place at Petal NGL Terminal.  The process at the facility is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation (Program 1).  Release prevention is provided throug

Petal NGL Terminal
Enterprise Products Operating L L C.
Executive Summary Risk Management Plan
EPA Identifier:  1000 0016 4387

Accidental Release Prevention and Response

At Enterprise, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of our emergency response program
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Petal NGL Terminal receives, transfers, and redistributes propane and a commercial butane mixture to wholesale customers.  The flammable products arrive at our facility via pipeline, rail car, or transport trucks.  The facility has several storage tanks and a propane dehydration unit associated with the transfer operations.  The two products are redelivered to wholesale customers for transport via pipeline, rail car or transport truck. Access to this site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel, maintenance contractors, transport truck drivers and rail car switching personnel.
